field_edited_text.value:
24

Analysis A great deal of planning analysis underlies the Valley
Plan. What will be the impact of the Expressway? Should
the Valley be used for industry? Must the entire Valley be
cleared to provide continuity for the Park? What would be
the costs and benefits? How could the Plan be implemented?
These questions and many others were studied and considered
before the Plan could be completed. Though only a summary
can be shown here, careful scrutiny of details by the City is
necessary.

The Impact of the Expressway on the Valley Impact studies of
expressways elsewhere have shown great increases in develop-
ment at the interchanges, particularly in industrial uses where
open, level land was available. The actual design of the
expressway was studied. Its impact could be good, or could
be very damaging to the adjacent land uses. The result of not
putting the Valley Plan into effect will mean some increases
in industrial use, but industry on the same hit-or-miss basis
as in the past.

Alternative Land Uses The predominant land use in the Valley
is already public. City-owned property — including parks,
playgrounds, schools, and the expressway — outstrip all other
uses by a tremendous margin. Other significant uses are resi-
dential and institutional. Primarily open and undeveloped
land still numbers in the hundreds of acres; much of it still
has great natural beauty.

How much of the Valley could be developed for new industry?
When the flood plain, steep topography, and land-locked sites
are all considered, there are only about 50 really good acres

for potential industrial use. These are scattered among 11
or 12 locations. Even some of these are partially within the
flood plain or in residential zones.

The present industry was examined. Although some concerns
are substantial, together they provide less than 2500 jobs. In
the course of the next 20 years of the Plan, many of the indus-
tries will move through need for more space, changes in
ownership, and obsolescence of structures. Therefore it was
considered not impractical to gradually retire the Valley from
industrial use.

The facts are that industrial opportunity here is a pittance.
And, in the overall picture of the Valley, industry is not a
large existing use. With planned industrial parks opening else-
where in the City, the marginal sites offered by the Valley
will continue to suffer from their historic competitive disad-
vantage in spite of the expressway.

Continuity of the Concept The big decision in the planning
process was that the Valley had to be continuous to be feasible
as a Plan. Schemes in which the Park was interrupted were
tried and rejected. They fell apart as mere spot park pro-
posals. The concept of a stream valley park from the Inner
Harbor to Lake Roland and beyond has integrity, historic
significance, and validity in both City and regional aspects of

‘geography and planning.

Costs While the study does not purport to contain a detailed
cost analysis, the general magnitude of costs is felt to be
realistic. For acquisition cost, recent comparable sales were
used for unimproved land. For improved parcels, 1960 assess-
ments were multiplied by a conservative factor. Costs are esti-
mated for the City portion only.

The ¥irst stage, a five-year plan, is'estimated to cost $10 mil-
lion; of this, $8.2 million is for acquisition and $1.8 million
for development. It will add 262 acres to the City’s park
system. The total 1960 assessment of real property of this
stage is less than $2 million.

The final stage, over 20 or more years, would add an additional
91 acres to the Park system at a cost of about $12.3 million;
$2.7 million is estimated for park and recreational develop-
ment. The 1960 assessment of real property of the final stage
is slightly over $5 million. Together, the two stages return
about $256,000 a year to the City in property taxes.
